column1: Retroperitoneal fibrosis is a rare disorder that blocks the tubes (ureters) that carry urine from the kidneys to the bladder.

Early symptoms: - Dull pain in the abdomen that increases with time - Pain and change of color in the legs (due to decreased blood flow) - Swelling of one leg Later symptoms: - Decreased urine output - No urine output (anuria) - Nausea, vomiting, changes in mental status caused by kidney failure and build-up of toxic chemicals in the blood - Severe abdominal pain with hemorrhaging (due to death of intestinal tissue)

Other tests that can help diagnose this condition include: - BUN and creatinine blood tests - Intravenous pyelogram (IVP), not as commonly used - Kidney ultrasound - MRI of the abdomen - CAT scan of the abdomen and retroperitoneum A biopsy of the mass may also be done to rule out cancer.
If corticosteroid treatment does not work, a biopsy should be done to confirm the diagnosis.
The disorder may lead to: - Ongoing blockage of the tubes leading from the kidney on one or both sides - Chronic kidney failure
This drug has been shown to cause retroperitoneal fibrosis.
